newsitem.title: USA: Cigarette tax hike proposal pending in Fla.-- paper.
newsitem.headline: Cigarette tax hike proposal pending in Fla.-- paper.

text.p: Florida Gov. Lawton Chiles, whose state is among those waging war on the tobacco industry, will propose raising the state cigarette tax by up to 10 cents a pack, Fort Lauderdale Sun-Sentinel reported Tuesday.
The proposal is part of Chiles' $41 billion budget to be released Wednesday, according to the newspaper. Chiles' budget aides could not immediately be reached for comment.
Florida taxes cigarettes at 34 cents a package, bringing in $750 million a year. A 10-cent-a-pack increase would bring in another $90 million annually.
Chiles' initiative would be more modest than the 18-cent-a-pack increase supported by the tobacco companies last year.

Associated Industries of Florida, a business lobby group that includes tobacco companies, proposed the cigarette tax last year as part of a deal in which the state would drop its lawsuit against cigarette makers.
That proposal fizzled and the lawsuit is still pending in Palm Beach County Circuit Court. It seeks to recover state health care costs attributed to smoking-related illnesses.
Four years ago, another Chiles proposal to raise cigarette tax by 25 cents a pack also failed.

John French, a lobbyist for Philip Morris USA, a unit of Philip Morris Cos Inc, told the Sun-Sentinel that Chiles' proposal seemed unlikely to pass in the current no-new-taxes environment, but was unsuprising.
"He's trying at every juncture to keep the pressure on the tobacco industry," the newspaper quoted French as saying.

The federal government levies a 24-cent-a-pack tax on cigarettes, while state taxes vary widely. Virginia has the lowest at 2.5 cents a pack, while Washington state has the highest at 81.5 cents a pack.
